description: The Bulgarian government has banned the entry of third-country (non-EU) nationals from March 20 to April 17. The Bulgarian government has also banned the entry of persons arriving from the following EU Member States and Schengen countries: Italy, Spain, France, Great Britain, Germany, the Netherlands, and Switzerland. Exceptions: healthcare professionals, health researchers and elderly care professionals, transport personnel engaged in the carriage of goods, crews of aircraft, diplomats, officials of international organizations, military personnel, and humanitarian workers in the performance of their duties, persons traveling for humanitarian reasons,third-country nationals who hold a long-term residence permit in an EU Member State and those transiting Bulgaria to return to their country of residence, Bulgarian citizens and their family members, or persons with permanent or long term residence permits and members of their families.

description: Bulgaria's Health Minister has issued a temporary ban on the entry into Bulgaria of third-country nationals outside the EU. The new order also bans the entry via all border crossings, with any kind of transport, regardless of their nationality, of persons coming from Italy, Spain, France, Great Britain, Northern Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria, Belgium, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Luxembourg. An exception is made for Bulgarian citizens and their families.

description: As of March 21, the Bulgarian Government decided to introduce checkpoints at the entry/exit roads to the district capitals and carry out checks on the purpose and destination of the journey. description: On 23 March a separate Medical Council for dealing with the coronavirus pandemic was appointed by the Prime Minister of Bulgaria. The Council's mission is to provide the government with complementary analysis and action proposals and the general public with professional guidance and information. Unlike the National Crisis-management Staff, which is a formal national institution with executive power and tasks, the Council has mostly a knowledge-based advisory role.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

type_text: The policy means to maintain the service of the public transport system in the conditions of the emergency situation. Therefore the working hours are reduced.

description: As of March 13, 2020 the Bulgarian government recommends to set-up anti-epidemic measures regarding the work environment. Foremost all employers should do everything to make home-office possible. If this isn't possible because of specific job-related characteristics, measures to decrease the danger of infection should be provided, such as disinfection, ventilation, personal hygiene awareness and reducing social contacts within the work environment to a minimum.

The Medical Expert Council with the Bulgarian cabinet has compiled a guide on successful Bulgarian and global strategies for coping with COVID-19. The 200-page report will be submitted for approval to the Bulgarian Ministry of Health and will then be available for use by all physicians in the country. This was announced on March 31, 2020.
On April 7, 2020 Bulgaria's Ministry of Health is introducing a National Information System for Combating COVID-19.

Bulgaria is enforcing a two-week quarantine on all passengers, including Bulgarian nationals arriving from or having visited China and Italy after Jan. 03. There is no information on when the policy is slated to end.

description: As of March 13, extracurricular activities for children and all public events in Bulgaria are suspended until March 29. UPDATE: Originally, sports events were suspended in regions with confirmed cases of COVID-19. On March 13, all public events are suspended until March 29.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On March 20 Bulgaria introduces a ban on visits to parks, city gardens, playgrounds, sports grounds, outdoor and indoor public places. People would be allowed to enter parks to walk their dogs, but must not do so in groups. From May 5 individual sports outside and visits to swimming pools are allowed. UPDATE: The policy forbade visits to sports grounds until the end of the emergency situation on May 13. Individual sports outside and visits to swimming pools are now allowed provided sufficient hygienic measures.

All extracurricular activities involving children and public events in Bulgaria are suspended until April 12. UPDATE: All extracurricular activities involving children and public events in Bulgaria were restricted until March 29. The suspension is extended to April 12.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: All extracurricular activities for children and public events in Bulgaria are suspended until May 13. UPDATE: The ban of extracurricular activities for children and public events in Bulgaria from March 13 had been extended until April 12. A new order extends this suspension until May 13.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On March 20 Bulgaria introduces a ban on visits to parks, city gardens, playgrounds, sports grounds, outdoor and indoor public places. People would be allowed to enter parks to walk their dogs, but must not do so in groups.

An order that takes effect on April 27 allows visits to public parks and gardens by children up to 12 years ago, accompanied by at most two family members, between 9.30am and 6.30pm daily. People may still walk their dogs alone in public parks and gardens up to 9.30am and after 6.30pm. UPDATE: An order that takes effect on April 27 allows visits to public parks and gardens by children up to 12 years, accompanied by at most two adult family members, between 9.30am and 6.30pm. Previously, visits to public parks were only allowed for people walking their dogs. They may still do so alone up to 9.30am and after 6.30pm.

As of May 1, 2020, the local authorities are requested to allow visits to national parks, nature parks, and mountains again by the Bulgarian government. UPDATE: After a total ban on visits to parks, city gardens, playgrounds, sports grounds, outdoor and indoor public places, the Bulgarian government now requested the local authorities to allow visits to national parks, nature parks, and mountains again.

As of March 13, 2020, the Bulgarian Government suspends and forbids consultations for children and pregnant women, prophylactic examinations and immunizations, planned operations, including the transplantation of organs from living and carcass donors, and visits to all medical establishments shall be suspended.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On March 13, 2020, the Bulgarian Government suspends and forbids consultations for children and pregnant women, prophylactic examinations and immunizations, planned operations, including the transplantation of organs from living and carcass donors, and visits to all medical establishments. UPDATE: Starting from April 21, Bulgaria will gradually restore the previously suspended operation of hospitals, consultations for children and pregnant women, and immunizations.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: On April 9, 2020, the Bulgarian Government recommended not to attend church services during eastern.

As of March 21, 2020, the Bulgarian government restricted the free entry to all parks, sport- and playgrounds and all other public indoor and outdoor places. As of April 26, the visit of parks is now allowed again for children up to 12 years accompanied by a parent or family member, but not more than two adults from 9.30 to 18.30 and for dog owners, but not more than one, until 9:30 and after 18:30
To be noted: Wearing of protective masks and keeping a distance of 2.5 meters obliged, alcohol consumption prohibited, contact with surfaces, including benches and lawns is to be avoided. This was announced by the Bulgarian Health Ministry. UPDATE: As of April 26, 2020, the visit of parks in Bulgaria is possible again under certain conditions. Originally the visit of parks was restricted without any exceptions.
